refnamediv.refpurpose: export cyclog logs to a remote log stash using the RSYSLOG protocol

refsection.title: Description
refsection.para: export-to-rsyslog scans directory for cursor directories. For each cursor directory found, it monitors the referenced log directory and outputs any log data newer than the cursor, saving the new cursor position.
It expects to inherit an open file descriptor, for writing each log line that it reads from a log to the RSYSLOG server. This is file descriptor 7 per the UCSPI convention for client tools.
It expects the file descriptor to be open for writing to a datagram or message socket or device. If it is a socket, it must be already connected so that the write2 system call works correctly.

export-to-rsyslog converts log lines that it has read into RFC 5424 form and then writes them to the server. It strips trailing newlines from each log line, converts initial TAI64N timestamps, and employs the result of the gethostname3 function and the name of the cursor directory in the HOSTNAME and APP-NAME fields. It writes each log line with a single system call in order to mark the message boundaries between log lines.

RFC 3164 form is ambiguous and extremely lossy and is not supported. RFC 5424 form is still lossy, but not quite as much since it permits full years and only loses microsecond and nanosecond information.

export-to-rsyslog treats TAI64N timestamps correctly. On a Linux system where it detects an Olson "right" timezone currently in use, it knows that the system clock is TAI seconds since the Epoch and performs a simple conversion to determine system clock time. On other Linux systems, and on BSDs, it assumes that the system clock is UTC seconds since the Epoch and attempts to correct for (known) UTC leap seconds in order to determine UTC system clock time.

refsection.title: CURSOR DIRECTORY
refsection.para: directory is a directory of cursor directories. Every subdirectory, or symbolic link to a directory, therein whose name does not start with a dot is a cursor directory. A subdirectory, or (more usually in practice) symbolic link to a directory, beneath each of those cursor directories that is named main is a log directory. See cyclog1 for the format of a log directory.

The cursor position is a TAI64N timestamp, in external form, stored in a file named last, defaulting to zero if that file is not present or does not contain a parseable TAI64N timestamp as its first line. This is the TAI64N timestamp of the last log entry that has been read from the log. All log entries, and log files, that are timestamped then or older are skipped over.

In order to be comparable to the current cursor position, all log lines must have valid TAI64N timestamps. This is always the case for correctly formatted log directories. Erroneous lines without TAI64N timestamps are skipped, therefore.
